History at Leeds Trinity & All Saints spans a wide range of periods and a spectrum of topics covering the local, national and international. Ranging from the Vikings to the 21st Century, modules include the French Revolution, the American Civil Rights Movement, Victorian Working Women, 17th Century Popular Culture, Life under Fascist and Communist Regimes, and Reporting Crisis: The Fall of Yugoslavia.

The course is Âhands onÂ, and you explore History in varied ways, including role play, site visits, historical investigation, and work placements in museums and heritage centres. To study at Leeds Trinity is to work within easy reach of the major cities, Leeds and Bradford, which spear-headed the Industrial Revolution, and also to be well-placed to explore the impact of industrialisation on the countryside. The History staff are key contributors to the internationally acclaimed Leeds Centre for Victorian Studies. They are also a close-knit and enthusiastic group, always keen to respond to student opinion.

• A course structured around transferable and historical skills, different periods and places.
  • A small cohesive department with excellent relationships between staff and students.
  • Varied and dynamic teaching methods including workshops, seminars, role-playing, CD-rom and internet applications.
  • Particular strength in the nineteenth century, with close links with the Leeds Centre for Victorian Studies and the Journal of Victorian Culture.
  • A strong vocational orientation, including career planning and workplace attachments.
  • An excellent graduate employment record.
  • Active programme of History and Heritage-related events, including our own exhibitions and conferences.
What jobs do History graduates get?

History studied on its own, or in combination with English, provides an excellent basis for a career in a wide variety of sectors. History at Leeds Trinity, with the opportunity to undertake a workplace attachment in school, is an ideal preparation for
the PGCE in either primary or secondary education.
Previous graduates are now employed in areas including business, government and public sector organisations, teaching, educational advisers and professional posts with the heritage industry.

Teaching methods are varied and include, in addition to lectures and seminars, one-to-one supervision, student-led individual and group work, fieldwork, role-play, and computer-assisted learning. You will be given a wide choice within modules and independent learning is encouraged.

Assessment is continuous, in the form of posters, reports, essays, and group and individual oral presentations. Written examinations are used for a few modules, in the form of both seen and unseen context and/or essay papers.

Vocational experience is an important element of the History degrees, involving placement within an external organisation. It is here that you may begin to determine where your particular area of interest lies, whilst gaining important practical skills.
Work placement opportunities have included: heritage centres such as Wigan Pier
column3: and museums such as the Royal Armouries, The Second World War Experience Centre, Beamish Open Air Museum, the museum at Kirkstall Abbey, Eureka, The World of James Herriot, the National Museum of Photography, Film and Television, and Leeds Thackray Medical Museum. Each year students planning to apply for teacher training undertake work placements in schools.

column1: History at Leeds Trinity is about developing practical historical skills, and at every stage supports your development as a historian. At Leeds Trinity you will be able to study, individually and in small groups, topics of your own choosing which are approved by your tutor, and so develop your own insights into particular areas of history. At the same time, you are developing skills and confidence which employers value, including the ability to gather and analyse complex information, the initiative to think critically and imaginatively, willingness to work well in a team, and the ability to express and communicate your findings clearly and persuasively.
